properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory for tonight and Wednesday. Lake effect snow bands and heavy flurries will move into the region tonight and shift back and forth across the region through Wednesday morning giving variable amounts of snow. Local amounts of 5 to 10 centimetres of snow can be expected by Wednesday morning. The heavier bands of snow will likely move north of Sault Ste. Marie on Wednesday morning. Travel may become hazardous at times tonight and on Wednesday due to accumulating snow and slippery conditions. Visibility could locally be reduced at times in heavy flurries. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T11:36:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-16T19:37:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1063167030.2021
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay, Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory for late this afternoon into tonight. Travel continues to be hazardous due to accumulating snow and local blowing snow. An additional 5 - 10 cm of snow is still possible. Motorists are advised to take care on the roads as the snow starts to accumulate. Slow down and maintain a safe following distance. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T12:31:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-16T20:32:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3369351491.2021
Area: Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and ice pellet accumulations are expected. Total amounts: 15 to 25 cm. Locations: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity; Burgeo - Ramea. Time span: continuing until overnight tonight. Remarks: Snow will transition through a period of ice pellets this evening before changing through freezing rain to rain later tonight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow continues to fall late this afternoon into this evening. Additional snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are still possible due to lake enhancement. Strong winds gusting up to 50 km/h are expected to produce local blowing snow in some places. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of freezing rain will continue. Locations: parts of Nova Scotia Time Span: until this evening. Remarks: Snow and ice pellets will transition to freezing rain and then to rain tonight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 35 cm is expected. Locations: Corner Brook and Gros Morne. Time span: this evening into Wednesday afternoon. Remarks: Snow and wind will combine to reduce visibility at times in blowing snow, especially over exposed areas. In the Corner Brook area, snow will likely mix with ice pellets overnight tonight and early Wednesday morning. Conditions will improve Wednesday afternoon as snow tapers off to flurries. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold wind chill values near minus 55 are expected return on Wednesday afternoon as winds increase. As the winds pick up tomorrow, it is likely that blowing snow will occasionally reduce visibility to less than 400 m. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Summary:

Remarks: Freezing rain will change to rain over Queen and Kings counties later this evening as temperatures continue to rise. In Prince County, pellets and freezing rain tonight will change over to flurries before morning. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls are moving into the area this afternoon and continue to affect areas near Lake Huron this evening. This snow is expected to be heavy at times and accumulations of 10 to 15 cm is possible. Strong winds and gusts of up to 50 km/h are expected to produce local blowing snow which could reduce visibility significantly. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. An Arctic ridge of high pressure has allowed for a very cold air mass to settle over southern Manitoba. Wind chill values between minus 20 and minus 30 are expected this afternoon as temperatures moderate. However, some regions could approach extreme cold wind chill values of minus 40 one last time tonight before temperatures begin to warm across the south Wednesday afternoon. ### Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T08:27:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-16T16:28:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3105462202.2021

properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls are expected to move in late this afternoon and continue this evening. This snow is expected to be heavy at times and accumulations of 10 to 15 cm is possible. Strong winds and gusts of up to 50 km/h are expected to produce local blowing snow which could reduce visibility significantly. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T10:20:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-16T18:21:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0499126381.2021
Area: London - Parkhill - Eastern Middlesex County, Strathroy - Komoka - Western Middlesex County, Goderich - Bluewater - Southern Huron County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. Locations: southern New Brunswick. Time span: tapering off overnight. Remarks: Freezing rain will continue for several hours before tapering off overnight. A changeover to rain is expected along some parts of the Fundy Coast. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T09:59:47-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Locations: Avalon, Burin, and Connaigre Peninsulas. Time span: tonight. Freezing rain amounts: 5 to 10 mm. Remarks: After a period of snow and ice pellets this evening, precipitation will transition through an extended period of freezing rain later tonight. Freezing rain will change to rain prior to morning on Wednesday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls are affecting areas close to Lake Huron and will move inland this evening. This snow is expected to be heavy at times and accumulations of 10 to 20 cm is possible. Strong winds and gusts of up to 50 km/h are expected to produce local blowing snow which could reduce visibility significantly. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow combined with strong northeasterly winds will reduce visibilities to near zero over these areas until this evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T06:59:10-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Locations: southern Avalon Peninsula. Total rainfall: 20 to 30 mm (highest amounts over extreme southern areas). Time span: overnight tonight into Wednesday morning. Remarks: Freezing rain will change to rain tonight and taper to showers Wednesday morning. Significant snowmelt and runoff are likely to occur. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total Snowfall: 25 to 35 cm. Maximum winds: east to northeast 40 gusting to 60 km/h. Location: the northeast coast of Newfoundland. Time span: this evening to Wednesday evening. Remarks: Visibility is expected to be poor, especially over exposed coastal communities, as snow combines with wind to produce blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve Wednesday evening as snow tapers off to flurries and winds begin to ease. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-17T10:59:49-00:00
